docs.snippet: Frank Gore had two second-half touchdowns and San Francisco rebounded from a 17-0 deficit against Atlanta to return to the Super Bowl for the first time since 1995....
docs.lead_paragraph: Frank Gore had two second-half touchdowns and San Francisco rebounded from a 17-0 deficit against Atlanta to return to the Super Bowl for the first time since 1995.
docs.abstract: San Francisco 49ers overcome 17-0 deficit to defeat Atlanta Falcons, 28-24, and advance to Super Bowl.

headline.seo: With Second-Half Rally, 49ers Top Falcons to Advance to Super Bowl
headline.main: 49ers Rally to Super Bowl, and Even Harbaugh Smiles
headline.print_headline:
It's Brother vs. Brother: 49ers Overcome 17-0 Deficit
To Reach Super Bowl

docs.snippet: Quarterback Matt Ryan could not have been more accurate for the first half of the N.F.C. Championship game. That all changed for the Falcons offense with an interception, fumble and dubious decisions on two incompletions....
docs.lead_paragraph: Quarterback Matt Ryan could not have been more accurate for the first half of the N.F.C. Championship game. That all changed for the Falcons offense with an interception, fumble and dubious decisions on two incompletions.
docs.abstract: Atlanta Falcons offense sputters in second half of NFC championship game against San Francisco 49ers, costing them the title.

headline.seo: Atlanta’s Fortunes Turn After a Slip and a Pick
headline.main: A Slip, Then a Pick, and Atlanta Tumbles Out

docs.abstract: Baltimore Ravens defeat New England Patriots, 28-13, to advance to Super Bowl; Ravens coach John Harbaugh will have opportunity for face his brother, San Francisco 49ers coach Jim Harbaugh.

docs.snippet: The disquieting reality of the struggle against segregation is that the conflict was not between good and evil, but between good and normal....
docs.lead_paragraph: The disquieting reality of the struggle against segregation is that the conflict was not between good and evil, but between good and normal.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Diane McWhorter maintains that the racists Rev Dr Martin Luther King fought against in Birmingham, Ala, have come to be characterized as cartoon bad guys, but were often ordinary people doing what was considered 'normal'; says painting segregationists as villainous racists allows people false sense of blamelessness.
